selected_quotes: Same medicine, different reasons: producing eggs for pregnancy or for profit - new paper @SocSocMed
My comparative survey of women's bodily experiences with IVF is out
Comparing women's bodily experiences of producing eggs for pregnancy or for profit.
#HealthEconJA Same medicine, different reasons: Comparing women's bodily experiences of producing eggs for pregnan…
Same medicine, different reasons: producing eggs for pregnancy or for profit - new paper

citation.abstract: Women doing in vitro fertilization (IVF) to have a child describe it as painful and emotionally draining. Egg donors undergo the same medical regimen for a different reason - to produce eggs for another woman in exchange for thousands of dollars - and describe it as quick and relatively painless. Medical researchers typically compare bodily responses by variables such as gender, age, and health status. We use the case of "egg production" to propose a new factor that may be an important source of variation in bodily experience: an individual's reason for undergoing the medical intervention in the first place. Using cluster analysis to analyze an original survey of 50 IVF patients and 62 egg donors from the United States, we find two distinct kinds of bodily experiences - "less intense" and "more intense" - and the intensity of one's experience is associated with one's reason for producing eggs: either to become pregnant or to donate them for money.
citation.title: Same medicine, different reasons: Comparing women's bodily experiences of producing eggs for pregnancy or for profit

news.title: Intensity of Bodily Experience During IVF is Associated With Reason for Producing Eggs
news.summary: IVF (in vitro fertilization) is the most common form of ART (Assisted Reproductive Technology).

news.title: For pregnancy or profit—motive for undergoing IVF may alter the experience
news.summary: An individual's reason for undergoing a medical intervention—be it to prevent or treat disease, earn money, or have a child—may result in variations in the bodily experience of the patient, Yale researchers have found.
